channel.title: NYT > Home Page
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Government Reopens, the New Congress Tries to Begin Again
item.media:description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi at the Capitol on Friday. The House will turn to legislation high on the Democrats’ priority list this week, including a bill to raise pay for civilian federal employees.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: The end of the shutdown means that the agendas of both chambers of Congress, overshadowed for weeks by the struggle to reopen government, will get a restart.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS

item.title: Your 2019 Tax Refund Might Be Higher, Lower or Later Than Usual
item.media:description: While furloughed federal workers will return to their jobs on Monday, it will take time to get parts of the I.R.S. running smoothly again.
item.media:credit: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg
item.description: It’s unclear how the Trump tax law will affect refunds in what has been a clockwork injection of cash into the economy. The shutdown’s effects are murkier still.
item.dc:creator: JIM TANKERSLEY and MATT PHILLIPS

item.title: On Washington: With Pain Still Fresh, Lawmakers Make Push to Outlaw Shutdowns
item.media:description: Reporters followed Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, on Thursday after two measures to reopen the government failed in the Senate.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: The toll of the latest impasse has prompted members of both parties to push for legislation that would ensure that the government wouldn’t be closed again as part of a budget negotiation.
item.dc:creator: CARL HULSE

item.title: America Pushes Allies to Fight Huawei in New Arms Race With China
item.media:description: Huawei’s offices in Warsaw. Polish officials recently came under pressure from the United States to bar Huawei from building its 5G communications network.
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.description: With 5G networks about to remake the internet, the Trump administration fears decisions made in the next six months on China’s role will resonate for decades.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER, JULIAN E. BARNES, RAYMOND ZHONG and MARC SANTORA
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The World Economy Just Can’t Escape Its Low-Growth, Low-Inflation Rut
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange this month. Markets went haywire at the end of 2018, but what story were they telling?
item.media:credit: Johannes Eisele/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Just when we thought we were out, global deflationary forces have pulled us back in.
item.dc:creator: NEIL IRWIN

item.title: To Rise Above the Democratic Pack, Elizabeth Warren Tries ‘Nerding Out’
item.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and her advisers believe her enthusiasm for policy details will inspire Democratic primary voters.
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Warren’s passion for policy minutiae has become her way of standing out in an increasingly crowded Democratic field. But some voters say she risks being seen as out-of-touch and too intellectual.
item.dc:creator: ASTEAD W. HERNDON

item.title: The Tabloid Myths of Jennifer Aniston and Donald Trump
item.media:description: The numerous tabloid reports that Jennifer Aniston is back together with Brad Pitt and pregnant are “completely false,” her publicist said.
item.media:credit: Valerie Macon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: She wants to reunite with Brad Pitt and have a baby. He’s a self-made guy from the streets. Or so certain segments of the media would have you believe.
item.dc:creator: JIM RUTENBERG

item.title: Bill de Blasio May Be Running for President, if Only People Would Listen
item.media:description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, speaking at the United States Conference on Thursday, intends to “preach the gospel” of liberal governance in appearances across the country.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. de Blasio, the mayor of New York, went to Washington to “preach the gospel” of liberal governance.
item.dc:creator: J. DAVID GOODMAN

item.title: These Patients Had Sickle-Cell Disease. Experimental Therapies Might Have Cured Them.
item.media:description: Brandon Williams received gene therapy to replace sickle cells with healthy hemoglobin. His sister, Britney, died of complications of sickle-cell disease. He has a tattoo of her name on his right arm.
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.description: Success against sickle-cell would be “the first genetic cure of a common genetic disease” and could free tens of thousands of Americans from agonizing pain.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: Elite Law Firm’s All-White Partner Class Stirs Debate on Diversity
item.media:description: A group of Paul, Weiss partners at the law firm’s Midtown Manhattan office with the chairman, Brad Karp, center in blue tie. “We have a very good track record in terms of diversity,” Mr. Karp said.
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.description: Paul, Weiss is more diverse at its top ranks than most of its peers. But its recent promotions underscored how far big firms have to go to elevate women and people of color.
item.dc:creator: NOAM SCHEIBER and JOHN ELIGON

item.title: Another Side of #MeToo: Male Managers Fearful of Mentoring Women
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence has said he never dines alone with a woman other than his wife, a maxim that has become widely known as the Pence Rule.
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images
item.description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, some male leaders said they were avoiding one-on-one time with junior female colleagues, a trend that could deprive women of valuable exposure.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Afghan Women Fear Peace With Taliban May Mean War on Them
item.media:description: Afghan women lining up to vote in a parliamentary election in Herat Province in October.
item.media:credit: Hoshang Hashimi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The idea of an American troop withdrawal fills Afghan women with dread, as they see Westerners as their only protectors not just from the Taliban, but also the “Taliban mentality” among other men.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND, FATIMA FAIZI and FAHIM ABED
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Huawei, Roger Stone, Venezuela: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: Poland is under pressure to limit its business dealings with Huawei. Above, Warsaw.
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Steve Jobs Never Wanted Us to Use Our iPhones Like This
item.description: The devices have become our constant companions. This was not the plan.
item.dc:creator: CAL NEWPORT

item.title: The Real Wall Isn’t at the Border
item.media:description: An aerial view of the fence between California and Tijuana, Mexico.
item.media:credit: Guillermo Arias/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: It’s everywhere, and we’re fighting against the wrong one.
item.dc:creator: ATOSSA ARAXIA ABRAHAMIAN

item.title: A Time to Remember Portugal’s Schindler
item.description: Aristides de Sousa Mendes, a diplomat who helped thousands of Jews escape the Holocaust, died a pauper.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD HUROWITZ

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Stone-Cold Loser
item.media:description: Roger Stone posed for a portrait in his Upper East Side apartment in 2015.
item.media:credit: Jesse Dittmar for The New York Times
item.description: Will the dawn raid on the Prince of Darkness shine a light on the Trump campaign’s original sin?
item.dc:creator: MAUREEN DOWD
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: A Case Against Impeachment
item.media:description: President Trump walks into the Oval Office after announcing a temporary end to the government shutdown on Friday.
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.description: Three (provisional) reasons not to put the president on trial.
item.dc:creator: ROSS DOUTHAT
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: She Wanted to Drive, So Saudi Arabia’s Ruler Imprisoned and Tortured Her
item.media:description: Loujain al-Hathloul recorded a video in 2014 showing her driving in the United Arab Emirates toward the border with Saudi Arabia.
item.media:credit: Loujain al-Hathloul, via Associated Press
item.description: The U.S. should pressure Saudis to respect the human rights of outspoken women.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The Loneliness of the Moderate Democrat
item.media:description: Gov. Gina Raimondo of Rhode Island. She argues that Democrats are too unfriendly to business.
item.media:credit: Gretchen Ertl for The New York Times
item.description: ‘It takes a lot of spine to be a centrist in America today.’
item.dc:creator: FRANK BRUNI

item.title: Saving NATO
item.media:description: President Trump with Mike Pompeo and John Bolton at a NATO summit in 2018.
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.description: The House voted overwhelmingly to block President Trump’s threat to quit the Atlantic alliance. The Senate should promptly follow suit.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Mueller’s Real Target in the Roger Stone Indictment
item.media:description: Roger Stone in Washington in December 2018.
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.description: It was probably not Stone himself, but rather his electronic devices.
item.dc:creator: JULIAN SANCHEZ
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: ‘This Is Our Land’
item.media:description: A digger with bags of cobalt in Kolwezi, Democratic Republic of Congo. Congo abounds in cobalt, crucial for electronic devices.
item.media:credit: Sebastian Meyer/Corbis News, via Getty Images
item.description: Mineral riches should make Congo prosperous. Instead, they fuel corruption, which has kept the people poor and compromised elections.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. KAVANAGH

item.title: The Secret Sushi Bar on the 10th Floor
item.media:description: David Bouhadana works behind his four-seat sushi counter.
item.media:credit: Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times
item.description: A controversial chef has created a sort of sushi speakeasy in a hotel room. It’s not easy to get a reservation. For one thing, there are only four seats at the bar.
item.dc:creator: HELENE STAPINSKI

item.title: Surfacing: In Britain, Enraptured by the Wild, Lonely and Remote
item.media:description: The Hutchison Memorial Hut, colloquially called the Hutchie Hut, illuminated by moonlight in Scotland’s Cairngorms National Park.
item.media:credit: Stephen Hiltner/The New York Times
item.description: Rustic shelters called bothies — more than 100 of which are scattered throughout England, Wales and Scotland — are an indispensable, if little-known, element of British hill culture.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN HILTNER

item.title: Big City: The Rich Didn’t Always Need $238 Million Penthouses
item.media:description: Brooke Astor, the socialite and philanthropist, seemed just fine living within 5,000 square feet.
item.media:credit: William E. Sauro/The New York Times
item.description: Wealthy Americans, like Ken Griffin, who bought a 24,000-square-foot apartment on Central Park, weren’t always obsessed with larger-than-fantasy real estate.
item.dc:creator: GINIA BELLAFANTE

item.title: Trump Thought Firing Flynn Would End ‘Russia Thing,’ Chris Christie Writes in Book
item.media:description: Chris Christie, a two-term governor of New Jersey, delivering the State of the State address in 2017.
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.description: The former New Jersey governor’s memoir paints President Trump as highly effective as a candidate — but someone who since has been ill-served by many advisers, including some members of his family.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Charles Kettles, Who Rescued Dozens of Troops in Vietnam, Dies at 89
item.media:description: Charles Kettles at the controls of an Army helicopter in 1954. Thirteen years later, in Vietnam, he led a rescue mission that eventually earned him the Medal of Honor.
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Charles Kettles
item.description: “A soldier who was there said, ‘That day, Major Kettles became our John Wayne.’ With all due respect to John Wayne, he couldn’t do what Chuck Kettles did.”
item.dc:creator: RICHARD GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Books News: Jay Asher, Author of ‘Thirteen Reasons Why,’ Files Defamation Lawsuit
item.media:description: In the wake of accusations of sexual misconduct, Jay Asher’s literary agency dropped him, speaking engagements and book signings were canceled, and some bookstores removed his novels from their shelves.
item.media:credit: Left: Steve Cohn/Netflix, via Associated Press
item.description: After accusations of sexual harassment were made public, Mr. Asher’s book sales declined, and he was dropped by his literary agent. He is seeking a trial and damages.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ALTER

item.title: Banksy Mural Is Stolen From Bataclan, Site of Paris Attacks
item.media:description: The mural attributed to Banksy appeared on a door to the Bataclan venue in June 2018.
item.media:credit: Thomas Samson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The venue said the work, painted on an emergency exit door, was a memorial to the victims of the 2015 terror attacks.
item.dc:creator: LAUREN MESSMAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Philippines Cathedral Bombing Kills 20
item.description: Scores more were wounded in twin blasts in a predominantly Muslim area of the southern Philippines where the government has been fighting Islamist separatists.
item.dc:creator: JASON GUTIERREZ

item.title: Too Ugly to Be Saved? Singapore Weighs Fate of Its Brutalist Buildings
item.media:description: The Pearl Bank Apartment in Singapore. So-called Brutalist landmarks are emerging havens for the sort of gritty, artsy subcultures that are mostly absent in Singapore.
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times
item.description: A few landmarks of so-called Brutalist architecture are on the verge of being sold to private developers, prompting a last-ditch scramble by enthusiasts to have the buildings protected.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Senator Joni Ernst Speaks Out About Being a Survivor of Sexual Assault
item.media:description: “What I want people to understand is that I am the same person as I was last week,” Senator Joni Ernst said. “You just know more about what’s inside of me now.”
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Ernst, Republican of Iowa, spoke out after court papers in her divorce briefly became public. She pledged to support other survivors.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH WILLIAMSON

item.title: On Tennis: Novak Djokovic Passes His Idol and Sets a New Target: Roger Federer
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic grew up idolizing Pete Sampras and now, at least in the record books, Sampras will have to look up to him.
item.media:credit: Kim Kyung-Hoon/Reuters
item.description: Djokovic broke a tie with Pete Sampras for third-most men’s Grand Slam titles by winning his 15th — the Australian Open — on Sunday. Federer’s record of 20 is within sight.
item.dc:creator: KAREN CROUSE

item.title: International Pickpockets Ride New York’s Subway, Pilfering and Profiting
item.media:description: International visitors who pick pockets lack a criminal history in New York, which is an advantage: When they are caught, they tend to get light sentences.
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.description: The thieves are not known to the police, which helps them evade detection. They also move from city to city, trying to stay ahead of investigators.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WILSON

item.title: How to Use ‘Do Not Disturb’ on Your Phone (While Still Letting Important Calls Through)
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.description: The bliss of turning off all notifications on your phone doesn’t have to come with the anxiety of potentially missing an important call or text. Here’s how you can have it all.
item.dc:creator: WHITSON GORDON

item.title: Playlist: The Playlist: Vampire Weekend’s Plucky Return, and 15 More New Songs
item.media:description: After a six-year gap, Vampire Weekend has returned.
item.media:credit: Byron Smith for The New York Times
item.description: Hear tracks by Phoebe Bridgers and Conor Oberst, Dua Lipa, J. Cole and others.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: Why People Ghost — and How to Get Over It
item.description: Time to go ghostbusting.
item.dc:creator: ADAM POPESCU

item.title: Crowdwise: How to Handle the Dreaded ‘Reply All Moment’
item.media:credit: Graham Roumieu
item.description: You know that sinking feeling when you accidentally click "Reply All" instead of "Reply?" It's awful. Here's how to handle it, and make sure it never happens again.
item.dc:creator: DAVID POGUE

item.title: Lens: Helen Levitt’s Street Photos Blend the Poetic With the Political
item.description: Examining the overlooked work of a photographer whose images brought awareness to social issues.
item.dc:creator: RENA SILVERMAN

item.title: What Penn Badgley Wants Us to Learn From ‘You’
item.description: When viewers swooned over his creepy character on the hit series, Badgley fired back on social media. Now, he reflects on his tweets and the show’s impact.
item.dc:creator: ELEANOR STANFORD

item.title: Critic’s Pick: Review: Revisiting a Film from Ida Lupino, Hollywood Star Turned Director
item.media:description: Sally Forrest plays a dancer who contracts polio, and Keefe Brasselle is her husband in Ida Lupino’s “Never Fear.”
item.media:credit: MoMA
item.description: “Never Fear,” a 1949 movie directed by Lupino that has been superbly restored, tells the story of a dancer felled by polio.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Social Q’s: Just So We’re Clear: I’m Also Paying the Bill
item.description: A gainfully employed reader wonders why her in-laws only ever thank her husband for picking up the tab.
item.dc:creator: PHILIP GALANES

item.title: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse’ and How a Scene Crawled to Life
item.description: The directors of the Oscar-nominated film discuss the spider-bite sequence that changes everything for its main character, Miles Morales.
item.dc:creator: MEKADO MURPHY

item.title: ‘This Could Be the End’ for NASA’s Mars Opportunity Rover
item.media:description: An artist's rendering of NASA's Opportunity rover on the surface of Mars.
item.media:credit: NASA, via Associated Press
item.description: The agency has received only silence from the intrepid explorer since contact was lost during a global dust storm on the red planet last June.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: ‘Hamlet’ in Virtual Reality Casts the Viewer in the Play
item.media:description: Steven Maler directed “Hamlet 360” and is the founding artistic director of Commonwealth Shakespeare Company. “This is a way to put into the classroom an extraordinary experience of this play,” he said.
item.media:credit: Cody O'Loughlin for The New York Times
item.description: A joint production by a Boston theater company and Google hopes to bring high-quality Shakespeare to wider audiences, and new audiences into theaters.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH A. HARRIS

item.title: Are Electric Cars Only for the Rich? Sacramento Is Challenging That Notion
item.media:description: Sarah Quismondo and Alberto Ayala at an Our CarShare location in Sacramento.
item.media:credit: Bradley Berman for The New York Times
item.description: With funding from a surprising source, Volkswagen, California is making sure low-income communities have the chance to gain access to electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: BRADLEY BERMAN

item.title: A Race Against Space
item.media:credit: Beatrice de Gea for The New York Times
item.description: One of the tenets of neurosurgery is that the cranium, the bone that encases the brain, can fit only so much.
item.dc:creator: ABDUL-KAREEM AHMED, M.D.
